docs.title: OpenVista - True Open Source geospatial platform
docs.text: OpenVista is an Open-source geospatial platform with capabilities of visualisation, management and analysis of multiple data types. It is built using modern web technologies and open-source libraries to provide a robust and scalable solution for geospatial data handling.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: OpenVista is designed as a modern, cloud-native geospatial processing platform using a microservices architecture. This design ensures scalability, maintainability, and flexibility for various deployment scenarios.

docs.title: System Architecture
docs.text:
graph TB
    subgraph "Client Layer"
        WEB[Web Applications]
        API_CLIENT[API Clients]
        GIS[GIS Software]
    end

    subgraph "API Gateway"
        FASTAPI[FastAPI Backend]
        TITILER[TiTiler Tile Server]
        PG_TILESERV[Vector Tile Server]
    end

    subgraph "Processing Layer"
        AIRFLOW[Apache Airflow]
        WORKER[Celery Workers]
    end

    subgraph "Storage Layer"
        MINIO[MinIO Object Storage]
        POSTGRES[(PostgreSQL + PostGIS)]
    end

    subgraph "Services"
        KEYCLOAK[Keycloak Auth]

        REDIS[(Redis Cache)]
    end

    WEB --> FASTAPI
    API_CLIENT --> FASTAPI
    GIS --> TITILER
    GIS --> PG_TILESERV

    FASTAPI --> KEYCLOAK
    FASTAPI --> POSTGRES
    FASTAPI --> MINIO
    FASTAPI --> AIRFLOW

    AIRFLOW --> WORKER
    WORKER --> MINIO
    WORKER --> POSTGRES
    POSTGRES <--> PG_TILESERV
    WEB <--> PG_TILESERV
    TITILER --> MINIO
    AIRFLOW --> REDIS

docs.title: 1. FastAPI Backend
docs.text:
Purpose: Main application API and business logic

  • Technology: FastAPI (Python)

  • Responsibilities:

    • REST API endpoints
    • Authentication integration
    • Data validation
    • Workflow orchestration
    • File upload/download management

docs.title: 2. Apache Airflow
docs.text:
Purpose: Workflow orchestration and task scheduling

  • Technology: Apache Airflow with Celery executor
  • Responsibilities:
    • Raster processing workflows
    • Terrain analysis pipelines
    • COG optimization tasks
    • Batch processing jobs

docs.title: 3. PostgreSQL + PostGIS
docs.text:
Purpose: Primary database for metadata and spatial data

  • Technology: PostgreSQL with PostGIS extension
  • Responsibilities:
    • User management
    • Raster metadata storage
    • Processing job tracking
    • Spatial queries and analysis

docs.title: 4. MinIO Object Storage
docs.text:
Purpose: Scalable object storage for raster data

  • Technology: MinIO (S3-compatible)
  • Responsibilities:
    • Raw raster file storage
    • Processed output storage
    • COG file hosting
    • Temporary processing files

docs.title: 5. Keycloak
docs.text:
Purpose: Identity and access management

  • Technology: Keycloak
  • Responsibilities:
    • User authentication
    • Authorization policies
    • JWT token management
    • Single sign-on (SSO)

docs.title: 6. TiTiler
docs.text:
Purpose: Dynamic raster tile server

  • Technology: TiTiler (FastAPI-based)
  • Responsibilities:
    • On-the-fly tile generation
    • Raster visualization
    • Web map integration
    • COG optimization validation

docs.title: 1. Raster Upload Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Client
    participant FastAPI
    participant Keycloak
    participant MinIO
    participant PostgreSQL

    Client->>FastAPI: Upload raster file
    FastAPI->>Keycloak: Validate token
    Keycloak-->>FastAPI: Token valid
    FastAPI->>MinIO: Store raster file
    MinIO-->>FastAPI: File stored
    FastAPI->>PostgreSQL: Save metadata
    PostgreSQL-->>FastAPI: Metadata saved
    FastAPI-->>Client: Upload complete

docs.title: 2. Processing Workflow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Client
    participant FastAPI
    participant Airflow
    participant Worker
    participant MinIO

    Client->>FastAPI: Request processing
    FastAPI->>Airflow: Trigger DAG
    Airflow->>Worker: Schedule task
    Worker->>MinIO: Download input
    Worker->>Worker: Process with GDAL
    Worker->>MinIO: Upload result
    Worker-->>Airflow: Task complete
    Airflow-->>FastAPI: Workflow complete
    FastAPI-->>Client: Processing done

docs.title: Horizontal Scaling
docs.text:
• Airflow Workers: Scale processing capacity by adding more worker nodes
  • FastAPI Instances: Load balance multiple API instances
  • Database: PostgreSQL read replicas for query scaling
  • Storage: MinIO distributed mode for high availability

docs.title: Vertical Scaling
docs.text:
• Memory: Increase RAM for large raster processing
  • CPU: More cores for parallel GDAL operations
  • Storage: SSD storage for faster I/O operations

docs.title: Authentication Flow
docs.text:
1. User Login: Keycloak handles authentication
  2. Token Generation: JWT tokens for API access
  3. Token Validation: FastAPI validates tokens on each request
  4. Authorization: Role-based access control (RBAC)

docs.title: Data Security
docs.text:
• Encryption: TLS/SSL for data in transit
  • Access Control: User-based file access permissions
  • Audit Logging: Complete audit trail of operations
  • Network Security: Container network isolation

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
• Single-node Docker Compose
  • Local file storage
  • Minimal resource requirements

docs.title: Production
docs.text:
• Kubernetes orchestration
  • Distributed storage
  • High availability configuration
  • Monitoring and alerting

docs.title: Cloud Native
docs.text:
• Managed database services
  • Object storage (S3, GCS, Azure Blob)
  • Container orchestration platforms
  • Auto-scaling capabilities

docs.title: Why FastAPI?
docs.text:
• High performance async framework
  • Automatic API documentation
  • Type hints and validation
  • Modern Python features

docs.title: Why Airflow?
docs.text:
• Mature workflow orchestration
  • Rich ecosystem of operators
  • Web-based monitoring
  • Scalable task execution

docs.title: Why MinIO?
docs.text:
• S3-compatible API
  • High performance
  • Kubernetes native
  • Open source

docs.title: Why PostGIS?
docs.text:
• Mature spatial database
  • Rich spatial functions
  • ACID compliance
  • Strong ecosystem support
